awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Three-dimensional, super-resolution, and super-sensitivity quantitative molecular multiphoton microscopy in living tissue
awd_abstract_narration:
ABSTRACT

PI: Howard, Scott
Proposal: 1554027


The goal of this CAREER proposal is to study, develop, characterize, and evaluate a fundamentally
new method for super-resolution molecular imaging in living animals. An approach capable of visualizing functional and morphological markers of pathological conditions located deep within the tissue would be a breakthrough in optical imaging and its applications in biomedical research and the development of novel therapeutic and diagnostic approaches. Significant efforts will be dedicated to teaching translational applications of biophotonics with emphasis on helping students develop entrepreneurship skills in the field of biophonics and imaging.

This proposal will provide researchers, for the first time, a platform for three-dimensional, super-resolution imaging deep in living animals while simultaneously providing super-sensitivity molecular measurements in the cellular microenvironment. This new super resolution molecular imaging modality is based on analyzing harmonic distortions in a multiphoton microscope. This is an ambitious goal and the idea of using saturation to further localize fluorescence signals is innovative.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF funded project “CAREER: Three-dimensional, super-resolution, and super-sensitivity quantitative molecular multiphoton microscopy in living tissue” successfully developed a new technical approach that drastically increased the imaging speed and sensitivity of three-dimensional microscopy of living animal tissue. This was accomplished by establishing a rigorous theoretical understanding of how the fluorescence lifetime of a protein or dye molecule can be measured more accurately with improved spatial resolution be exploiting the subtle effects of fluorescence saturation. By using a “frequency domain” approach (i.e., by exciting the sample with a pulsing laser beam and measuring the properties of the emitted pulses), the project found that analysis of the “harmonic distortions” of the emitted fluorescence light from a tissue sample yield both high spatial resolution and highly sensitive measurements of molecular interactions at the sub-cellular level.

Using this knowledge, a new type of microscope system called “Instant FLIM” was developed that enabled, for the first time, fluorescence lifetime imaging of the entire 3D volume of living animal tissue with fast enough imaging rates to create 3D microscopic movies of what happens inside of cells during brain injury. Mouse brain vasculature and fluorescently labeled microglia were imaged using a multiphoton Instant FLIM system through an intact mouse skull. To study the speed, spatial, and chemical resolution of the system, the Instant FLIM system was used to image recovery to laser-induced localized thermal damage in mouse brain and zebrafish embryo spinal cord development. In total, 14 peer-review papers were published covering the wide gamut from fundamental physical models up to system evaluation in living animals. The technology platform has also been subsequently adopted by and is in use in several institutions globally, including Harvard Medical School.

The broader impacts of the work include both technical, educational, and entrepreneurial efforts. The technical broader impacts include the development and distribution of several new open-source microscopy tools including a trained neural network that can nearly instantly denoise an image, a tool that automates fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy segmentation using machine learning, and a tools that enables researchers to perform super-resolution microscopy using conventional scanning microscopy platforms by exploiting the subtle effects of saturation that occur in fluorescence microscopy. This grant supported the development of a new undergraduate course at the University of Notre Dame, “Biomedical Device Engineering,” which quickly became one of the most popular (and in some years the most popular) elective in the Department of Electrical Engineering. The grant also supported a high-school program in collaboration with the Wyandanch School District’s (Long Island, NY) P-TECH (Pathways to Technology) Program to bring highly talented students and teachers and students to Notre Dame’s campus. During their time on campus, they participated in a bio-photonics design module and were exposed to college admissions, financial aid, and aspects of student students were not previously exposed to or aware of. Additionally, the work impacted entrepreneurial efforts including sponsoring multiple undergraduate student teams in “Startup Weekend” entrepreneurial training (one winner, and one runner-up). Notre Dame filed and received two patents for the work developed in this grant, and is actively working with industry to commercialize the technology.
